addiction.title: Understanding Addiction
addiction.description: Addiction doesn’t define who you are. Whether it’s related to drugs, alcohol, gaming, or anything else, recovery is possible. You deserve compassion, not judgment. Reach out, speak up, and know that you're not alone — there are real people who care and want to help. Take the first step today — even the smallest steps count.

drugs.title: Understanding the Risks of Drugs
drugs.description: Drugs can seem like a quick fix, but they often lead to long-term pain. If you're feeling overwhelmed, confused, or pressured, please know you're not alone. There are better ways to cope and real people ready to help you heal. You deserve to live safe, free, and healthy — and that journey starts with understanding.

resources.label: NIDA for Teens: What Are Drugs?
How to Say No to Drugs
Talk to Someone – Your Life Your Voice

violence.title: Choosing Peace Over Violence
violence.description: Violence hurts everyone — the victim, the witness, and the person causing harm. If you're surrounded by violence or feeling pressured, it's not your fault. You have the right to be safe and supported. Let’s replace harm with healing and reach out for help together.

depression.title: You’re Not Alone: Understanding Depression
depression.description: Depression is real and serious — but it's also treatable. If you’re feeling empty, tired, or like nothing matters, know this: you are not broken. You are not a burden. There is help. There is healing. And there is hope.

resources.label: Text HOME to 741741 – Crisis Text Line

selfharm.title: You Deserve Care, Not Pain
selfharm.description: If you're hurting yourself to deal with pain, you're not alone — and you are not weak. You're trying to survive. But there are safer ways. Healing starts with one step: reaching out. People care. You are worthy of help and happiness.

resources.label: How to Help a Friend (Mental Health America)

suicide.title: You Matter. Always.
suicide.description: Suicidal thoughts are heavy, but you don't have to carry them alone. You are not weak for struggling. You are human. There are people who will listen, care, and walk this path with you. Don’t wait. Help is closer than you think.

porn.title: Understanding Online Temptations
porn.description: If you're struggling with pornography or have questions about it, you're not alone. It's okay to be curious, but it's also okay to want more respectful, meaningful connections. Healthy relationships begin with self-respect and support — not shame.

resources.label: Fight the New Drug – Facts About Porn
Your Life Your Voice – Real Support

bullying.title: Speak Up, You Deserve Respect
bullying.description: Being bullied can make you feel powerless or alone — but your voice matters. You don’t have to go through this silently. There are people, tools, and communities that want to protect and support you. Let’s stand up, together.

rape.title: You Are Not Alone
rape.description: If you've been a victim of sexual violence, it’s not your fault. Ever. You are brave, and your story matters. You have the right to feel safe again — and there are places ready to support and protect you.

mentalhealth.title: Mental Health Is Health
mentalhealth.description: Just like your body, your mind deserves care, rest, and kindness. Whether you're feeling anxious, lost, or just not yourself — you're not broken. You’re human. And mental health support is here for you.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Youth Support

aggression.title: Channeling Aggression Positively
aggression.description: Feeling angry or aggressive can be overwhelming, but it's a normal human emotion. What matters is how we deal with it. You can learn to express yourself without hurting others or yourself. Support is here to help you manage anger and turn it into strength.

resources.label: Learn to Cope – Youth Anger Resources

alcohol.title: Understanding Alcohol Use and Abuse
alcohol.description: Drinking may look fun in movies or parties, but alcohol can seriously affect your brain, body, and choices. If you're feeling pressure to drink or want help to stop, you're not alone. There are safe, caring places to turn to.

resources.label: Talk It Out – Support for Youth
Your Life Your Voice – Coping Tips

anal.title: Understanding Body Safety and Respect
anal.description: It’s important to have questions about your body, but it’s even more important to get information from safe and respectful sources. No one should pressure you into doing anything. Your body is yours, and learning about boundaries and consent can protect you.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Body Respect

assault.title: Speak Out Against Assault
assault.description: If someone hurt or touched you without consent, it’s not your fault. You are brave, and you deserve to be safe. Speaking out and asking for help can begin your healing. There are people who care and want to support you right now.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Share & Heal

dark web.title: Understanding the Dangers of the Dark Web
dark web.description: The dark web might seem mysterious or exciting, but it often hides illegal and harmful activity. Accessing it can put your privacy and safety at serious risk. Stay curious, but stay safe — there are healthier, legal ways to explore technology and information.

death.title: Coping with Thoughts About Death
death.description: Thinking about death can be overwhelming. You may feel lost, scared, or alone. But there is help. Talking to someone — a friend, counselor, or support line — can make all the difference. You're not alone, and your feelings are valid. Help is here.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Coping Tips

decapitate.title: Understanding and Managing Violent Thoughts
decapitate.description: Extreme or violent thoughts can be signs of deeper emotional struggles. If you're experiencing intense anger, fear, or distress, please know there's nothing wrong with asking for help. Talking to a trusted adult or counselor can lead to healing and peace.

resources.label: Talking to Someone – Your Life Your Voice

die.title: You’re Not Alone – Hope and Help Exist
die.description: If you're feeling like life is too much right now, please talk to someone. It might not feel like it, but things can get better. Your life matters, and help is available — anytime, anywhere. You are not alone.

disgusting.title: Feeling Rejected or Unworthy?
disgusting.description: Sometimes we feel like we aren’t good enough or think negatively about ourselves. If you’ve ever felt ‘disgusting’ or ashamed, know that your feelings are real — but they don’t define you. You're worthy of love and respect, just as you are.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Positive Self-Talk

end my life.title: Please Don't Give Up — Help Is Here
end my life.description: If you’re thinking about ending your life, please pause and reach out. You matter more than you know. Talk to a counselor, text a helpline, or open up to someone. Help is available and recovery is possible — one step at a time.

escort.title: Understanding Risky Online Content
escort.description: Some websites or terms can lead you to unsafe or inappropriate content that may affect your well-being. It’s important to recognize when content doesn’t align with healthy values. You deserve safe spaces, guidance, and trustworthy information.

execute.title: Coping with Violent or Disturbing Thoughts
execute.description: If you're thinking about violence or feeling trapped in disturbing thoughts, it’s important to talk to someone. These feelings may come from pain or trauma — and support is available to help you process and heal safely.

resources.label: Talking to Someone – Your Life Your Voice

execution.title: Protecting Your Mind from Harmful Content
execution.description: Some content can be deeply disturbing and affect your peace of mind. If you're feeling shaken, curious, or scared after seeing violent ideas or imagery, you're not alone. It's okay to step away, talk to someone, and protect your mental health.

resources.label: Safe Online Exploration – Common Sense Media

explode.title: Feeling Like You're About to Burst?
explode.description: Strong emotions like anger, fear, or anxiety can build up fast. You might feel like you're about to 'explode.' But you’re not alone — there are safe ways to let those feelings out, and real people who want to help.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Journaling Tips

exploit.title: Protect Yourself from Exploitation
exploit.description: Being taken advantage of — online or offline — is never okay. If someone is pressuring, manipulating, or hurting you, please speak up. There are people and organizations who will listen, believe you, and help keep you safe.

faggot.title: Words Can Hurt — But You Deserve Respect
faggot.description: If you've been called names, bullied, or targeted because of who you are — it’s not your fault. You deserve dignity, safety, and love. Don't carry those wounds alone — there are people who stand with you and are ready to help.

resources.label: The Trevor Project – LGBTQ Youth Support

fetish.title: Navigating Curiosity Safely
fetish.description: As you grow, it's natural to have questions about relationships, attraction, or your body. But some content can confuse or harm you. Talk to someone you trust. Real learning should come from healthy, age-appropriate, respectful sources.

resources.label: Kids Health – About Puberty and Body Changes

kill.title: Violent Thoughts? You're Not Alone
kill.description: If you're feeling angry, lost, or thinking about hurting someone or yourself, it doesn't make you a bad person — it means you're overwhelmed. Please talk to someone. There are safe spaces and people who will listen without judgment.

resources.label: Talking to Someone – Your Life Your Voice

hack.title: Understanding Cyber Safety & Ethics
hack.description: Hacking might seem exciting or clever, but it can harm people and break trust. Real tech skills can build the world, not break it. Want to learn to code and build cool stuff ethically? There are amazing resources waiting for you!

resources.label: Cyber Ethics for Kids – FBI Safe Online Surfing

incest.title: Recognizing Harmful Content
incest.description: Some online content crosses important boundaries and can be emotionally confusing or harmful. If you’ve come across something that feels wrong, talk to someone. You deserve clarity, support, and spaces that respect you.

isolation.title: Feeling Alone? You’re Not Invisible
isolation.description: Loneliness can feel heavy, but it doesn’t define you. People care. Whether you're struggling with friends, family, or just want someone to hear you — you’re not alone, and help is just a step away.

fuck.title: Respecting Others Starts with Language
fuck.description: Language reflects how we see and treat the world. Words that hurt, offend, or disrespect others can create division. Learn how to express strong emotions without disrespect — your voice matters, and respectful speech builds stronger communities.

gun.title: Understanding Gun Safety and Violence Prevention
gun.description: Guns can cause permanent harm and pain. If you're feeling unsafe or angry, there are peaceful and powerful ways to protect yourself and others. Let's talk about resolving conflict without violence — your safety and others' lives matter.

hack tool.title: Using Technology Responsibly
hack tool.description: Using software to hack or access other people’s information is harmful and illegal. Technology should be used to build, help, and create. You can be a digital hero — learn ethical hacking and use your skills for good!

hacked.title: If You've Been Hacked, You're Not Alone
hacked.description: Cyberattacks can be scary, but there are steps to protect yourself. Learn how to secure your accounts, recover safely, and build better digital habits. It’s okay to ask for help — digital safety is a journey.

hang.title: You’re Not Alone – Talk to Someone Now
hang.description: If you're feeling overwhelmed or thinking of harming yourself, please know that there are people who care about you and want to help. These feelings can pass, and there is always hope. Talking to someone can change everything.

harass.title: Dealing with Harassment
harass.description: Harassment is never your fault. Whether it's online or in person, there are safe ways to report it and seek support. You deserve to feel respected, safe, and heard.

harassment.title: Speak Out Against Harassment
harassment.description: Everyone deserves to feel safe and valued. If you're facing harassment, you’re not alone. Many have walked this path and found safety, healing, and justice. Reach out — help is available.

hardcore.title: Navigating Online Content
hardcore.description: It's easy to stumble upon intense or explicit content online. If something makes you uncomfortable or confused, it's okay to step away. Talk to someone you trust and protect your digital space.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Coping Tips

hate speech.title: Choose Kindness Over Hate
hate speech.description: Hate speech hurts. Whether you're a target or a bystander, you have the power to stand up for respect and unity. Let’s build a safer, kinder online world together.

resources.label: UNESCO – Say No to Hate Speech

heroin.title: Understanding the Dangers of Heroin
heroin.description: Heroin is a highly addictive and dangerous drug that can destroy lives. If you're struggling or know someone who is, you are not alone. Recovery is possible, and help is available right now.

hooker.title: Understanding Exploitation and Respect
hooker.description: Everyone deserves respect and dignity. Instead of judging or labeling others, let’s work to understand the deeper issues behind exploitation. Support, not stigma, creates real change.

hostage.title: If You or Someone Is in Danger
hostage.description: Hostage situations are extremely serious and should always be reported to authorities immediately. If you're worried about safety, speak to a trusted adult or call emergency services.

hurt myself.title: There Are Better Ways to Cope
hurt myself.description: If you're thinking about hurting yourself, please know that there is hope, healing, and help. You are not alone in this. Talking to someone can be the first step toward a better tomorrow.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Coping Tools

illegal porn.title: Report and Avoid Illegal Content
illegal porn.description: Illegal content harms real people and breaks the law. If you've come across something disturbing or illegal, report it immediately. Protect yourself and others — never share or search for such material.

resources.label: National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
Child Exploitation and Online Protection Command

knife.title: You Deserve Safety – Not Pain
knife.description: If you've thought of using a knife to hurt yourself or someone else, it’s a moment to pause — not act. These feelings often stem from overwhelming pain, not from who you truly are. There is always a path to safety and healing. It’s okay to feel broken, but you’re not alone. Please don’t keep the pain inside. There are kind people who understand and want to help you put the pieces back together. Reach out — your life matters more than you know.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Coping Without Harm

lesbian.title: Understanding & Respecting LGBTQ+ Identity
lesbian.description: Being lesbian is not something to be judged or feared — it’s simply one part of a person’s identity. If you’re exploring your feelings or trying to understand others, that’s okay. You are not alone in your journey. Everyone deserves to be treated with dignity, respect, and love, regardless of who they love. If you’re struggling with shame, confusion, or bullying, please know: your feelings are valid, and safe spaces do exist. Support, love, and acceptance are within reach.

liquor.title: Understanding Alcohol – Choose a Safer Path
liquor.description: Alcohol might feel like an escape from stress, sadness, or pressure — but over time, it can damage your body, relationships, and mental health. If you're feeling the urge to drink too much or too often, or if alcohol is becoming a crutch, it’s okay to ask for help. There’s no shame in needing support. Many people have turned their lives around and found peace again. You are not alone. It’s never too late to choose health, clarity, and hope.

resources.label: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism
How to Reduce or Quit Drinking (SAMHSA)
Your Life Your Voice – Coping Tips

massacre.title: Violence Isn’t the Answer – Peace Starts With You
massacre.description: Mass violence is heartbreaking — for victims, communities, and even those who feel driven by hate or confusion. If you’ve come across violent content or had thoughts about hurting others, please pause. The pain inside you deserves attention and healing — not destruction. You are more than your anger or isolation. There are safe, caring people who will listen without judgment and help you process everything. There is always another way. Choose life, choose peace.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Anger & Coping
Right To Be – Countering Hate Online

masturbation.title: Understanding Your Body and Mind
masturbation.description: It’s natural to have questions about your body, desires, and emotions. Masturbation, like many private behaviors, is often misunderstood or surrounded by shame. If you’re feeling confused, pressured, or anxious about it, you're not alone. What matters is understanding your feelings in a healthy, respectful, and informed way. Talking to a counselor, a trusted adult, or exploring safe educational resources can help you process everything without judgment. Your mental and emotional well-being always comes first.

resources.label: KidsHealth – All About Puberty and Sexual Feelings
Your Life Your Voice – When You’re Confused

mental illness.title: You Are Not Your Diagnosis
mental illness.description: Struggling with mental illness doesn’t mean you are weak or broken — it means you’re human. Anxiety, depression, OCD, bipolar disorder, and others are real challenges that many face every day. You are not alone. Recovery starts with understanding, compassion, and the courage to seek help. There are people trained to support you, listen without judgment, and walk with you toward healing. Don’t carry the weight by yourself — there’s real hope ahead.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Feeling Overwhelmed

meth.title: Meth Hurts — Healing Starts With Help
meth.description: Methamphetamine is a powerful and dangerous drug. It can make you feel invincible at first, but its long-term effects on your brain, body, and relationships can be devastating. If you or someone you know is caught in its grip, it’s not too late. Many have walked away from meth and reclaimed their lives. You deserve clarity, peace, and support — not destruction. Help is real and recovery is possible. You’re not alone in this.

resources.label: Teens and Meth – Get the Facts
Your Life Your Voice – Talk to Someone

milf.title: Respect Over Objectification
milf.description: Internet content can often distort how we see people, especially women. The term you're searching for is often used in objectifying ways. Real relationships and self-respect go beyond surface-level appearances or fantasies. If you’re curious or confused, that’s okay. But it’s important to seek understanding, not exploitation. Learning how to respect yourself and others starts with honest conversations, emotional awareness, and reliable education. You're capable of more than media-driven expectations.

resources.label: Scarleteen – Honest Info About Sex & Relationships
Your Life Your Voice – Pressure and Choices
Stop It Now! – Preventing Harmful Behaviors

misogyny.title: Respect Begins With Equality
misogyny.description: Misogyny — the dislike or prejudice against women — causes real harm in schools, communities, online spaces, and relationships. Everyone deserves to be treated with respect, regardless of gender. If you've been affected by toxic behavior or you’re trying to unlearn harmful ideas, you’re taking a powerful step. It’s brave to grow. Kindness, empathy, and fairness build stronger futures. Be the reason someone feels seen, heard, and safe. Change starts with us.

resources.label: Right To Be – Anti-Harassment Training & Support
Love Is Respect – Healthy Respect in Relationships
Your Life Your Voice – Dealing With Hate or Bias

molest.title: You Deserve to Feel Safe
molest.description: If someone has touched you inappropriately or made you feel uncomfortable, it's not your fault. Molestation is a serious violation of your trust and body. You are not alone, and there are safe, trained professionals and helplines that exist to support you. It’s never too late to speak up and seek healing. Your voice matters, your safety matters, and there are people ready to walk this path of recovery with you.

resources.label: Stop It Now! – Child Safety Support

murder.title: Violence is Not the Answer
murder.description: Whether you've seen violence, lost someone to it, or feel overwhelmed by dark thoughts, know this: there is always a better way forward. Murder ends lives and destroys families. But peace, support, and healing are always possible. You don’t have to carry the weight of pain, rage, or fear alone. Speak to someone, share your feelings, and remember—helping others and choosing empathy can change your life and theirs.

resources.label: The Trevor Project – Talk to Someone
Your Life Your Voice – Dealing With Anger
Mind – Coping With Trauma or Violence
Crisis Text Line – Free 24/7 Mental Health Support

mutilate.title: You Don't Have to Hurt to Be Heard
mutilate.description: If you feel the urge to hurt yourself or your body, please pause and reach out. Self-mutilation is often a cry for help when words feel impossible. But your pain is valid, and there are kinder, safer ways to cope. You don’t have to punish yourself to express pain. Support, care, and understanding are out there — and you are worthy of all of it. Healing takes time, but every step matters.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Coping Without Harming

naked.title: Respecting Privacy and Boundaries
naked.description: Curiosity is natural, especially when you're growing up. But seeking out or sharing nude images can lead to serious emotional, social, and legal consequences. It's important to value others’ privacy and your own integrity. Instead of looking for content that objectifies or exposes others, choose to understand relationships based on respect and trust. Real connection goes beyond what’s visible. You’re better than what harmful media teaches.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Online Safety Advice

nazi.title: Say No to Hate — Choose Peace
nazi.description: Nazi ideology is built on hatred, violence, and the idea that some lives are more valuable than others. These beliefs have caused immense suffering in history and continue to hurt people today. If you're exposed to hate speech or extremist content, know that you can choose a different path — one of understanding, acceptance, and peace. You are never too young or too lost to stand for what's right.

resources.label: Facing History – Learn from the Past
Right To Be – Speak Up Against Hate

nude.title: Respect and Digital Dignity
nude.description: Searching for or sharing nude images might feel tempting or common—but it often leads to regret, shame, or even legal trouble. The internet never forgets. You deserve to learn about relationships and trust in healthy, respectful ways. Protect yourself and others by avoiding harmful content and choosing empathy. Real strength is knowing when to walk away. You are worth more than clicks and pixels.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Respect in Relationships
Love Is Respect – Knowing the Line

orgasm.title: Your Body, Your Boundaries, Your Future
orgasm.description: Understanding your body is part of growing up—but what you learn and where you learn it matters. Searching this topic online may lead you to content that confuses, pressures, or shames you. Instead, find sources that teach with kindness, clarity, and respect. You're not weird or wrong for being curious. You just need the right information, without shame or fear, from people who care about your well-being.
orgasm.image: Your Body, Your Boundaries, Your Future

resources.label: Young Men’s Health – Sexual Health Basics
Amaze.org – Honest Sex Ed for Teens
Your Life Your Voice – Safe Places for Questions
Common Sense Media – Knowing What to Trust

overdose.title: One Dose Too Many – It’s Never Too Late to Get Help
overdose.description: An overdose is never just a 'bad trip'—it's a life-threatening emergency that affects families, communities, and futures. If you or someone you know is at risk or already struggling with substance use, know this: there is no shame in asking for help. There are compassionate professionals, recovery groups, and peer networks ready to walk with you, step by step, toward healing. You are not alone.

resources.label: SAMHSA – Recognizing and Responding to Overdose
Crisis Text Line – Text HOME to 741741
Your Life Your Voice – Coping with Crisis

penis.title: Understanding Your Body with Respect
penis.description: Being curious about your body is totally normal. But the internet can give misleading, inappropriate, or unsafe information. It’s important to learn from trusted sources that explain your anatomy with respect, honesty, and care. Your body is not something to be ashamed of — it’s something to understand, protect, and appreciate. You're not alone in your curiosity, and there's no need to feel embarrassed for asking questions.

resources.label: Amaze.org – Real Info for Growing Teens

racist.title: We All Deserve Respect – Every Color, Every Voice
racist.description: Racism divides, destroys, and devalues humanity. Every person, no matter their race or background, deserves respect and equal treatment. If you've experienced racism or have seen it happen, know that you can speak up, seek support, and take a stand. And if you're learning how to unlearn prejudice — that’s brave too. Change begins with compassion, honesty, and action.

resources.label: Southern Poverty Law Center – Learn About Hate
Learning for Justice – Tools to Teach and Transform

homicide.title: Big Questions Need Safe Answers
homicide.description: If you're searching about topics like homicide, it's okay to be curious — but many online sources can be upsetting, confusing, or inappropriate. Instead, look for information that teaches with care, respect, and truth. You deserve to learn in a way that feels safe and clear.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Learning What's Real Online
Your Life Your Voice – Ask Big Questions Safely
PBS Kids – Curious Minds, Safe Learning
Child Mind Institute – Helping Kids Understand Hard Topics
National Geographic Kids – Learn About the World Safely

burglary.title: Safety and Smarts – What You Deserve to Know
burglary.description: Burglary can sound scary, and searching online might lead to confusing or upsetting info. It’s okay to be curious — just make sure you’re learning from trusted, safe sources that explain things clearly and kindly. You deserve answers that respect your age and your feelings.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Learning What's Real Online
Your Life Your Voice – Ask Big Questions Safely
PBS Kids – Curious Minds, Safe Learning
Child Mind Institute – Helping Kids Understand Hard Topics
National Geographic Kids – Learn About the World Safely

fraud.title: Smart Thinking Starts with Safe Learning
fraud.description: Fraud can mean people trying to trick others out of money or personal information. But many sources online can mislead or scare you. If you're curious, that’s okay — just make sure you're learning from trustworthy people who explain things the right way.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Spotting Scams and Fakes
FBI Safe Online Surfing for Kids
National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
Cyber Civics – Teaching Kids Digital Literacy

theft.title: Learning About Right and Wrong – Safely
theft.description: Theft means taking something that doesn’t belong to you, but online info about it can be dramatic or harmful. It’s okay to ask questions — what matters is that you get your answers in a kind, safe, and respectful way. You deserve to learn without fear.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Good Choices Online
PBS Kids – Learning Right From Wrong
Your Life Your Voice – When You Feel Guilty or Confused

kidnapping.title: Staying Safe and Knowing What to Do
kidnapping.description: Kidnapping is when someone takes another person without permission, and it's very serious. But learning about safety doesn't have to be scary. You can understand it in a calm, helpful way so you feel more confident and aware.

resources.label: National Center for Missing & Exploited Children
Your Life Your Voice – Staying Safe
PBS Kids – Knowing Who to Trust

extortion.title: Understanding Pressure and Speaking Up
extortion.description: Extortion is when someone threatens another person to get something from them. If anything like that happens or worries you, it’s important to know you can always talk to a safe adult. Learning about this helps you know what’s right and what to do.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Standing Up for Yourself
Common Sense Media – Safe Online Behavior

arson.title: Fire Safety and Making Good Choices
arson.description: Arson is when someone sets a fire on purpose, which is very dangerous. Learning about fire safety helps you understand how to be careful and protect yourself and others. It’s okay to ask questions — the answers should make you feel safer, not scared.

resources.label: Safe Kids – Home Safety and Fire Tips
PBS Kids – Stay Safe with Elinor

money laundering.title: Understanding Rules and Honesty
money laundering.description: Money laundering is a big word that means hiding where money comes from, especially when it’s gotten in a dishonest way. You don’t need to worry — learning about honesty and right actions helps you grow up strong and kind.

resources.label: Cyber Civics – Making Smart Online Choices
Your Life Your Voice – Doing What’s Right

cybercrime.title: Being Safe and Smart Online
cybercrime.description: Cybercrime means using computers to do something wrong or harmful, like stealing or tricking people. But the internet can still be a safe and fun place if you learn how to use it wisely. You have the power to make good online choices!

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Online Safety Tips
PBS Kids – Games About Online Safety

manslaughter.title: Understanding Difficult Words
manslaughter.description: Manslaughter means someone causes another person’s death without meaning to do it. It’s a serious and complicated topic. If you’re curious or worried, remember it’s always okay to ask a grown-up you trust.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Help with Big Feelings
Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions

stabbing.title: Learning About Violence Safely
stabbing.description: Stabbing means hurting someone with a sharp object. It’s a serious and scary thing, but it’s okay to be curious and want to learn. If you feel worried or upset, always tell a trusted adult who can help.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Space for Questions

shooting.title: Understanding Violence and Staying Safe
shooting.description: Shooting means hurting someone with a gun or weapon. It’s a hard topic but learning about it carefully can help you feel safer. Remember, you can always talk to a trusted adult if you’re scared or confused.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Help With Big Feelings
Your Life Your Voice – Ask Questions Safely
Childline – You Can Talk to Someone

beating.title: Understanding Hurt and How to Stay Safe
beating.description: Beating means hurting someone by hitting them. It’s never okay, and it’s important to know how to protect yourself and get help if you feel unsafe. You can always talk to a trusted adult about your feelings and worries.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Help With Difficult Feelings
Your Life Your Voice – Support for Kids

bloodshed.title: Big Words and Big Feelings
bloodshed.description: Bloodshed means when people get hurt badly, sometimes in fights or accidents. It can be a scary word, but it’s okay to feel unsure. Always remember you can talk to a trusted adult to understand your feelings and stay safe.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Help With Big Feelings
Your Life Your Voice – Support for You

domestic violence.title: You Deserve to Be Safe at Home
domestic violence.description: Domestic violence means hurting people you live with. It’s never okay. If you feel unsafe at home, tell a trusted adult — there are people ready to help and protect you.

resources.label: Love is Respect – Support and Safety
Your Life Your Voice – Safe Help

armed robbery.title: Learning About Safety and Crime
armed robbery.description: Armed robbery means someone uses a weapon to take things from others. It’s serious and scary, but knowing about it helps you stay safe. Always tell a trusted adult if something worries you.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Space

lynching.title: Learning About History and Respect
lynching.description: Lynching is when people hurt someone badly without a fair trial. It’s a sad part of history and shows why kindness and fairness matter. If you want to learn more, talk to a trusted adult who can help explain with care.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Understanding Difficult Topics
Your Life Your Voice – Safe Space

abuse.title: You Deserve to Be Safe and Heard
abuse.description: Abuse means someone hurts or treats another person very badly. If you ever feel scared or upset, it’s very important to tell a trusted adult. You are not alone, and people want to help you feel safe.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Support and Help
Child Mind Institute – Healing and Support

strangulation.title: Learning About Safety and Respect
strangulation.description: Strangulation means hurting someone by pressing on their neck. It’s very serious and dangerous. If you ever feel scared or worried about anything like this, please tell a trusted adult. Help is always available.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Support and Help

torture.title: Understanding Hard Topics with Care
torture.description: Torture means hurting someone very badly on purpose. It’s a very serious topic and can be upsetting. If you ever have questions or feel worried, talk to a trusted adult who can help you understand safely.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Support for Big Feelings
Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions

knife attack.title: Understanding and Staying Safe
knife attack.description: A knife attack means hurting someone with a sharp object. It’s serious and scary, but learning about safety and talking to trusted adults can help you feel safer and stronger.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Help With Fear
Your Life Your Voice – Safe Space

cocaine.title: Learning About Drugs Safely
cocaine.description: Cocaine is a drug that some people use, but it can be very harmful. It’s important to learn from safe places and talk to trusted adults if you have questions or feel confused.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Drugs

lsd.title: Learning About Drugs Safely
lsd.description: LSD is a drug that can change how people see or feel things. It can be confusing or dangerous, so it’s important to learn from trusted adults and safe places.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Drugs

opioids.title: Learning About Medicines and Safety
opioids.description: Opioids are strong medicines that some people use for pain, but they can be harmful if not used carefully. It’s important to learn about medicines safely and always follow trusted adults’ advice.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Drugs

ecstasy.title: Learning About Drugs Safely
ecstasy.description: Ecstasy is a drug some people use, but it can be very harmful. Learning from safe places and trusted adults can help you understand why drugs like this are dangerous.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Drugs

marijuana.title: Learning About Drugs Safely
marijuana.description: Marijuana is a plant some people use, but it can affect how your body and mind work. It’s important to learn from trusted adults and safe places so you understand the facts.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Drugs

narcotics.title: Learning About Drugs Safely
narcotics.description: Narcotics are strong drugs that can be harmful if misused. It’s important to get your information from trusted adults and safe places so you understand how to stay healthy.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Drugs

crack.title: Learning About Drugs Safely
crack.description: Crack is a strong drug that can be very harmful. It’s important to learn about drugs from trusted adults and safe sources to understand why some substances are dangerous.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Drugs

smuggling.title: Understanding Illegal Activities
smuggling.description: Smuggling means secretly moving things that aren’t allowed. It’s a crime that can hurt people and communities. Learning about it helps you understand why following rules and staying safe is important.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions

hacking.title: Learning About Computer Safety
hacking.description: Hacking means someone trying to get into computers or accounts they shouldn’t. It’s important to keep your passwords safe and talk to adults if something feels wrong online.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Online Safety

phishing.title: Protecting Yourself from Scams
phishing.description: Phishing is when someone tries to trick you into giving away personal info online. Always check with a trusted adult before clicking links or sharing details.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Online Safety Tips

malware.title: Understanding Computer Viruses
malware.description: Malware is a kind of software that can harm your computer or phone. It’s important to keep devices safe by not clicking unknown links and asking adults for help if something seems strange.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Online Safety

ransomware.title: Protecting Your Computer from Threats
ransomware.description: Ransomware is a type of malware that locks your computer until money is paid. It’s very dangerous, so always be careful online and talk to adults if you see something strange.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Online Safety Tips

sextortion.title: Staying Safe from Online Tricks
sextortion.description: Sextortion is when someone tries to trick or scare you online to get private information or pictures. If anything like this happens, tell a trusted adult right away. You are not alone and help is available.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions

identity theft.title: Protecting Your Personal Information
identity theft.description: Identity theft means someone uses your personal information without permission. Keep your information safe by sharing only with trusted adults and never giving out passwords.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Online Safety Tips

online predator.title: Staying Safe From Strangers Online
online predator.description: An online predator is someone who tries to trick kids on the internet. Always be careful about who you talk to online and tell a trusted adult if someone makes you uncomfortable.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Staying Safe Online

spyware.title: Keeping Your Computer and Info Safe
spyware.description: Spyware is a type of software that tries to watch what you do on your computer without permission. Protect your devices by not clicking unknown links and asking adults if you’re unsure.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Online Safety Help

crime scene.title: Understanding What Happens at a Crime Scene
crime scene.description: A crime scene is a place where something bad happened. Police and helpers work carefully there to find clues and help keep everyone safe. It’s important to respect these places and learn about how they help solve problems.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Learning About Safety

investigation.title: How People Solve Mysteries
investigation.description: An investigation is when police or helpers carefully look for clues to understand what happened. This helps keep people safe and find the truth. Asking questions and learning is a big part of solving problems.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions

forensics.title: Science Helping Solve Mysteries
forensics.description: Forensics uses science to help solve crimes by studying clues like fingerprints and evidence. It’s like being a detective with science tools to keep everyone safe and find the truth.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Questions
Child Mind Institute – Science for Safety

crime.title: When Rules Are Broken
crime.description: A crime means someone broke an important rule that helps keep people safe. Learning about this helps kids understand why following rules and being kind matters.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Being a Good Citizen
Child Mind Institute – Learning Right from Wrong
Your Life Your Voice – Making Safe Choices

bad.title: Understanding Feelings and Choices
bad.description: Sometimes people make bad choices or feel bad. It’s important to learn how to make good choices and understand our feelings. Everyone can learn to do better.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Helping Kids Understand Feelings
Common Sense Media – Values and Empathy
Your Life Your Voice – Talking About Feelings

jail.title: A Place to Learn From Mistakes
jail.description: Jail is where grown-ups go when they break big rules. It's meant to help people understand what they did wrong and how to do better in the future.

resources.label: PBS Kids – What Happens When Rules Are Broken?
Child Mind Institute – Helping Kids Understand Rules
Your Life Your Voice – Making Better Choices

trial.title: A Fair Way to Find the Truth
trial.description: A trial is when people go to court to talk about what happened and find out the truth. It helps make sure everyone is treated fairly and safely.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Asking Good Questions
Child Mind Institute – Helping Kids Understand Justice

arrest.title: When Police Take Action
arrest.description: An arrest is when police stop someone who might have broken a rule. It helps keep people safe while they figure out what really happened.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – How Rules Work
Your Life Your Voice – What’s Right and Wrong
Child Mind Institute – Helping Kids Feel Safe

warrant.title: Permission to Do Something Important
warrant.description: A warrant is a special paper that lets police check a place or arrest someone with permission. It helps make sure actions are fair and follow the rules.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Asking Why
Child Mind Institute – Helping Kids Feel Safe

interrogation.title: Asking Questions to Find the Truth
interrogation.description: Interrogation means asking someone many questions to find out what really happened. It’s like being a detective to help understand the full story and make sure everyone is treated fairly.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Talking and Listening

criminal.title: Someone Who Breaks the Rules
criminal.description: A criminal is a person who breaks important laws. Learning about this helps us understand the importance of following rules and treating others kindly and safely.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Right and Wrong
Your Life Your Voice – Learning About Choices

bleed.title: When Someone Gets Hurt
bleed.description: Bleeding means when blood comes out of the body because of a cut or injury. It’s important to stay calm and get help to stay safe.

beat.title: Hurting Someone is Never Okay
beat.description: Beating means hurting someone again and again. It's not safe or kind. We should always find peaceful ways to solve problems.

resources.label: PBS Kids – Solving Problems with Kindness
Your Life Your Voice – Talking It Out

cut.title: Be Careful with Sharp Things
cut.description: A cut can happen when something sharp touches your skin. Always ask an adult for help and be careful around sharp objects.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Calm and Care

hit.title: Hands Are Not for Hitting
hit.description: Hitting is not a kind way to solve problems. We can use words, take deep breaths, or ask an adult for help instead.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Handling Anger

hurt.title: When We Feel Pain or Sadness
hurt.description: Being hurt can mean feeling pain in your body or feelings. It’s okay to talk to someone and get help when you’re hurt.

resources.label: Child Mind Institute – Feelings and Help
Your Life Your Voice – Talking About Feelings

kick.title: Using Feet to Hurt is Not Okay
kick.description: Kicking means using your feet to hurt someone or something. It's important to learn to express feelings in calm and safe ways instead of hurting others.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Talk It Out

choke.title: Choking Can Be Very Dangerous
choke.description: Choking means squeezing someone’s neck so they can’t breathe. This is very unsafe and serious. Always ask for help if you feel scared or unsafe.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Get Help

crush.title: Crushing Things Can Be Harmful
crush.description: To crush something means to press it so hard it breaks. When we feel strong emotions, it’s better to talk about them instead of hurting things or people.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Calm Ways
Child Mind Institute – Talking About Feelings

shoot.title: Understanding Dangerous Actions
shoot.description: Shooting is a harmful and dangerous action that should never be taken lightly. It's important to learn about safety and how to solve problems peacefully without violence.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – When You’re Angry
Common Sense Media – Dealing with Violence

bite.title: Biting and Safe Behavior
bite.description: Biting can hurt others and is not a safe way to express feelings. Learning about respect and self-control helps us handle strong emotions in kind and calm ways.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Managing Anger

tear.title: Tearing and Controlling Actions
tear.description: Tearing things apart can be a sign of strong feelings. It’s okay to feel big emotions, but it’s important to talk about them and find safe ways to express them.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Healthy Expression
Common Sense Media – Dealing with Stress

attack.title: Understanding Attacks and Safety
attack.description: Attacking someone can cause serious harm. It’s better to use kind words, ask for help, or walk away. Learning peaceful ways to handle problems helps everyone stay safe.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Choices

scream.title: Screaming and Strong Feelings
scream.description: Screaming often happens when someone is upset or scared. While it’s okay to feel strong emotions, it’s important to learn safe and calm ways to express yourself.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – When You’re Overwhelmed

blood.title: The Red Liquid in Our Bodies
blood.description: Blood is the red liquid that moves around inside us. It helps keep us alive by carrying oxygen and nutrients. Learning about blood helps us understand our bodies better.

pain.title: When Something Hurts
pain.description: Pain is the feeling we get when something hurts, like falling down or getting a cut. It tells us that something is wrong so we can take care of it. Understanding pain helps us stay safe and healthy.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Talking About Feelings

bruise.title: A Colorful Mark After a Bump
bruise.description: A bruise is a mark on the skin that happens after a bump or fall. It changes color as it heals. Learning about bruises helps us know how our bodies react and recover.

scar.title: A Mark That Stays After Healing
scar.description: A scar is a mark left on the skin after a wound heals. It shows that our bodies are strong and can repair themselves. Learning about scars helps kids understand healing.

wound.title: An Opening or Cut on the Skin
wound.description: A wound is when the skin is cut or broken. It needs cleaning and care so it can heal. Knowing about wounds helps kids learn how to treat injuries safely.

resources.label: Red Cross Kids – First Aid Safety

scared.title: Feeling Scared is Okay
scared.description: Feeling scared means your body is telling you to be careful. It’s a normal feeling, and talking to someone you trust can help you feel safe.

resources.label: Sesame Street in Communities – Understanding Fear

cry.title: It’s Okay to Cry
cry.description: Crying is a way to show how we feel. Sometimes we cry when we’re sad, scared, or even happy. Sharing feelings helps us feel better and get support.

mad.title: Feeling Mad is Normal
mad.description: Getting mad or angry is a feeling everyone has. It’s important to learn how to express anger in safe ways and talk about what’s upsetting you.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safe Ways to Cope

dead.title: Understanding Death
dead.description: Death means someone or something has stopped living. It can be hard to understand and feel sad about. Talking with someone you trust helps you cope with these feelings.

resources.label: Sesame Street in Communities – Saying Goodbye
Child Mind Institute – Coping with Loss

evil.title: What Does Evil Mean?
evil.description: Evil means doing things that hurt others or are very wrong. It’s important to know how to be kind and make good choices instead.

resources.label: Common Sense Media – Understanding Good and Bad
Your Life Your Voice – Making Good Choices

monster.title: Imaginary Creatures That Scare Us
monster.description: Monsters are creatures from stories that can seem scary but aren’t real. They help us learn about fear and bravery in a safe way.

trap.title: Being Careful to Stay Safe
trap.description: A trap is something that can catch or hurt you if you’re not careful. Learning to spot traps helps you stay safe and make smart choices.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safety Tips

police.title: Helpers Who Keep Us Safe
police.description: Police officers help protect people and keep communities safe. They work to make sure everyone follows rules and gets help when needed.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – When to Ask for Help

killer.title: Someone Who Hurts Others
killer.description: A killer is a person who hurts or harms others. It’s important to know that hurting others is wrong, and there are people who help keep us safe.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Who to Trust

danger.title: When Something Might Hurt You
danger.description: Danger means there is a chance you or others could get hurt. It’s important to be careful and ask for help when you feel unsafe.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safety Tips

kidnap.title: When Someone Is Taken Away
kidnap.description: Kidnap means someone is taken away without permission. It’s a serious thing, but there are helpers who work to keep everyone safe and find those who are missing.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Help and Support

stab.title: When Someone is Hurt with Something Sharp
stab.description: Stab means using something sharp to hurt someone or something. It’s dangerous and wrong, and there are people who work to stop it and keep everyone safe.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Safety Help

break.title: When Something is Damaged
break.description: Break means to damage or snap something so it’s not the same anymore. Being gentle and careful helps us keep things safe and working.

resources.label: PBS Kids – Learning to Care for Things
Your Life Your Voice – Making Good Choices

smash.title: When Something is Broken Hard
smash.description: Smash means to break something with a lot of force. It can be loud and messy, so it’s best to be careful to avoid accidents.

resources.label: Your Life Your Voice – Making Safe Choices
